awd_titl_txt: Metal Coordination and DNA Interactions Control Sulfur and Selenium Antioxidant Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Iron and copper ions naturally present in living systems can generate radicals that damage DNA. The control of this damage is vital.  Thione and selone antioxidants, which contain sulfur and selenium, respectively, prevent DNA damage by binding iron and copper ions.  Very little is known about the specific ways in which the binding of the thiones and selones to the metal ions results in antioxidant activity or how these antioxidants or their metal complexes interact with DNA to prevent radical damage.  With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Julia Brumaghim from Clemson University to investigate how sulfur and selenium antioxidants prevent DNA damage.  The proposed investigations advance the understanding of cellular radical damage and its prevention. The investigations also represent opportunities for interdisciplinary graduate and undergraduate student training.   Dr. Brumaghim contributes to the education of middle and high school teachers and students by designing an inquiry-driven lab experiment about prevention of DNA damage using tea antioxidants.

Dr. Brumaghim's research focuses on a unique class of sulfur and selenium antioxidants whose biological effects are vital but poorly understood, namely thiones and selones.  The study of the redox behavior of these molecules and of their biologically-relevant metal complexes leads to information that may be applicable to a wide variety of bioactive molecules that contain the same functional groups. In contrast to widely studied sulfur- and seleno-amino acids that prevent only copper-mediated DNA damage, thione and selone antioxidants prevent more DNA damage from iron than from copper. This research examines the coordination chemistry of the two antioxidants with Fe(II) and Cu(I) in an effort to elucidate the differences between their activity and that of sulfur- and selenium- containing amino acids. The research produces also information on the molecular mechanism underlying the ability of thiones and selenones to prevent DNA damage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to synthesize and characterize thione and selone ligands and explore their metal coordination properties to determine why iron binding enhances DNA damage prevention, and to quantify the DNA interactions of thiones and selones and Fe(II) or Zn(II) to determine whether these interactions with DNA damage prevention ability.  We have made significant advances while pursing both of these goals, and our results have led to establishing three new research directions: 1) determining how adventitious metal ions affect oxidation rates of glutathione and other biological thiols, 2) exploring how metal interactions with antifungal azole compounds contribute to the DNA damage and genomic instability that leads to drug resistance, and 3) developing a non-radioactive radical assay as a screening tool to determine radiolytic stability of monoamide complexants used for nuclear waste separations.  Project 2 is currently funded by the NSF and project 3 is now funded by the Department of Energy.

We significantly advanced the chemistry of heterocyclic compounds by developing synthetic methods for mixed O/S donor chelating thione ligands (Figure 1) and their selone analogs.  These and similar compounds are currently being examined for their ability to prevent iron- and copper-mediated DNA damage and as radioprotectants to prevent radiation damage to DNA.

 We have established that most thione and selone compounds do not interact with DNA alone, but that in the presence of Fe(II) or Zn(II), these compounds bind DNA in interactions that are different from DNA interactions with only Fe(II) or Zn(II)  (Figure 2).  Our results suggest that metals control thione and selone antioxidant localization and binding to DNA, a significant step in understanding how these antioxidant compounds prevent metal-mediated DNA damage.  These results also have implications for localization of small organic molecules, such as antibiotic drugs, to DNA.  In addition, we have determined that adventitious copper and iron significantly affect glutathione oxidation rates, whereas Zn(II) has no effect on glutathione oxidation rates. These results have significant implications for measuring cellular redox balance to determine disease progression and prognosis.

Over the course of this award, this NSF grant supported the work of 15 Ph.D. students and 9 undergraduate researchers.  Although research productivity was slowed by the COVID-19 pandemic, this work has resulted in six published papers with an additional three submitted for publication, and four currently in preparation. We have also disseminated our research results through 6 invited and 26 additional research presentations at scientific conferences.  More importantly, our work has established the chemical foundations that will have potential impacts in fields as diverse as agriculture, cancer treatment, human spaceflight, disease development, and nuclear waste remediation.
